data.title: Jonah Hill 'hated' Superbad co-star after being 'attacked' in auditions
data.meta_description: Jonah Hill initially couldn't stand the thought of acting alongside Christopher Mintz-Plasse for the iconic 2007 hit comedy, which made the movie bosses even more convinced to hire him.
data.text:
Watch the trailer for Superbad (2007)

Jonah Hill “immediately hated” his Superbad co-star Christopher Mintz-Plasse - and told the film’s co-writer that he simply “couldn’t perform with that guy” as he was “f***ing with my rhythm”.

Seth recalled the actors’ squabbles 15 years after the iconic movie hit screens in a roundtable with Vanity Fair and other pivotal members of Superbad’s cast and crew.

Executive producer Judd Apatow added that Jonah’s dislike for Christopher was rooted in the 17-year-old’s “very caustic” personality and claimed he “attacked Jonah” with insulting improv during his third callback.

Jonah became adamant that he didn’t want Christopher on the movie, but this just furthered Judd’s resolve.

The founder of Apatow Productions declared: “I said; ‘That’s exactly why we’re hiring him. It couldn’t be more perfect. The fact that it bothers you is exactly what we want’."

Christopher on the other hand seemingly didn’t hold back on his auditions as he simply felt he would never get the role.

Superbad was the actor’s very first movie role and he recalled asking Seth to sign his script at the auditions because he thought he wouldn’t be back.

Looking back now, Jonah admitted that Christopher got under his skin simply because he was “really amazing off the bat”, which he found quite “annoying at the time”.

Despite their earlier scruples, Jonah and Christopher would go on to work together on a myriad of other shows and movies over the years, including more box office hits like How to Train Your Dragon and This Is The End.

Although it was Jonah’s intense dislike that sealed the deal for Christopher on Superbad, the 21 Jump Street star almost didn’t get his own starring role to begin with.

The movie’s director, Greg Mottola, told that outlet that despite Jonah’s “great” audition, at 23 he felt the actor was too old to be playing a high schooler alongside 18-year-old Michael Cera and 17-year-old Emma Stone.

But Jonah was relentless, insisting he should take the lead role despite being rejected “like 100 times” according to the movie’s co-writer Evan Goldberg.

He recalled: “He said, ‘No, you’re too old looking. I’m not! I can do this with makeup and hair’.”

Determined to prove his point, the actor taped himself doing some scenes using every tool at his disposal to visibly look younger.

The tape instantly made it clear to the filmmakers that he “should’ve been cast a long time ago”, with Judd declaring it “ridiculous” that they thought they would find another actor to fit the role like Jonah had.
